1984: A dystopian novel set in a totalitarian society ruled by Big Brother, where independent thinking is punished. Winston Smith secretly rebels, seeking truth and freedom.
The Hobbit: Bilbo Baggins, a comfort-loving hobbit, is swept into an epic quest to help dwarves reclaim their homeland from the dragon Smaug. Themes of courage, friendship, and adventure dominate the tale.
Pride and Prejudice: Elizabeth Bennet navigates societal expectations, family pressures, and her own judgments in this witty romantic drama centered around love, class, and personal growth.
The Art of War: An ancient Chinese military treatise by Sun Tzu offering strategic insights on conflict, leadership, and planning that are still applied in modern warfare and business.
The Martian: Astronaut Mark Watney is stranded on Mars and must use his ingenuity and engineering skills to survive until rescue. A gripping story of human resilience and science under pressure.
To Kill a Mockingbird: Set in the racially charged American South, the novel follows Scout Finch as her father, Atticus, defends an innocent black man. It explores themes of justice, morality, and childhood innocence.
The Alchemist: Santiago, a young shepherd, embarks on a journey across deserts to find treasure, only to discover deeper truths about following one's personal legend and listening to oneâ€™s heart.
The Book Thief: Narrated by Death, this story follows Liesel, a girl in Nazi Germany who steals books and learns the power of words during a time of horror, love, and war.
Circe: In this mythological retelling, Circe, daughter of the sun god Helios, is banished to an island and must discover her own powers and purpose as a witch defying gods and fate.
Life of Pi: After a shipwreck, a young boy named Pi is stranded in a lifeboat with a Bengal tiger. A philosophical and spiritual exploration of survival, storytelling, and faith.
